Actually He was school-time friend in Haryana. Politics was never his aim. Never.

He belonged to a very rich family. His father was a business man. I mean he is one. To be precise, he was related to construction business which was prospering like, damn !

You might be knowing that BJP Government is steadily bringing reforms in such sectors, several that type businessmen have suffered-are suffering under new policies. Since earlier there was almost no accountability and illegal things were common . Now all things are getting regulated, ESPECIALLY THE REAL ESTATE ONES. EARLIER IT WAS REGULAR FOR SUCH TYPE OF PROFFESSIONALS TO BREAK NORMS.

Since many of you might be left-adhering people, I know you will call me a BJP supporter, Bhakt and all sorts of names, but I need to admit-

Accountability has increased drastically under the Modi Government, in all sectors- I mean it.

This doesn’t mean I am their supporter. I am highly critical of their economic policies, and many other things. But they have shown outstanding performances in many sectors.

Corruption is one such sector.

Anyways, coming to Rathe issue, know that his father’s businesses were severly affected by the entry of the new government.

Illegal things became rare, I mean in many places, not all. But many. Rules and regulations need to be followed now and you can’t fool the government. That’s a fact.

HIS FATHERS BUSINESS GOT AFFECTED TO CORE.

Demonetization further curbed the black money of thousands. In India’s enemy nation(s), billions of dollars now became mere paper.

Yes, the common civilians suffered to a large extent but the heavy positives, no one highlights.

GST too is one such program which has sucked the hell out of these type

of people.

Just look at his earlier videos. His style is completely like ‘’a child hating the class monitor’’.

Just have a look at his earlier videos.

Even I was affected by the new policies of the modi government. A big part of my own house was brought down by machines. Although it was my fault, since we had encroached upon public land.

I personally observed many of my nieghbours who too were affected similiarly, they became devastatingly critical of BJP.

Maybe its justified, maybe its not. I won’t judge. But this is simply what I observed.

Dhruv knows that if BJP comes down, all those pre-2014 norms will again become common.

17:06 - One correction here, Amit Shah mentioned "Poverty" whereas our finance minister mentioned "Multi-Dimensional Poverty". There a difference here, a person may have crossed the Nation's "Below Poverty Line" but may still be counted as Multi-Dimensionally Poor. 

This is because Multi-Dimensional Poverty Index takes into account various other aspects such as Health[Nutrition + Child Mortality Rate], Education[Years of schooling+school attendance] and Standard of Living[Cooking Fuel, Sanitation, Drinking water, electricity, Assets and Housing]. This is a comparitively wider and longer process. This data is backed by the "Discussion Paper Released by NITI Aayog on Multidimensional Poverty in India".

Whereas Amit Shah wanted to highlight the Job opportunities that Atmanirbhar Bharat has created for the Indians. 

Therefore both are not lying as they both are not talking about the same thing. @dhruvrathee

This is news channel

There is a difference between multidimensional poverty and poverty.
Poverty typically refers to the lack of material resources or income to meet basic needs, such as food, shelter, and clothing. 
Multidimensional poverty, on the other hand, considers a broader range of factors beyond just income, such as access to education, healthcare, clean water, sanitation, and other essential services. It provides a more comprehensive understanding of deprivation by assessing various dimensions of well-being simultaneously.
So, both the numbers as stated by Nirmala Sitharaman and Amit Shah are correct.

So the summary of all this explanation is that GDP and GDP per capita has grown, but wealth inequality has also become more prevalent. For majority of Indians, who constitute the bottom 60% of our population, their share in India's economy has declined.
This has been like taking 1 rupee, from each of 1000 different people, and giving 1100 rupees to a an already rich guy. 
So the average income might have technically increased, but most of the people still got poorer.

Land cost around Rs. 25-30 lakhs per 1000 sq. feet in small towns of north india. Construction cost is around 20 lakh per floor having only basic amenities. So, 50 lakh rs. needed for house of single floor. Flat also cost around 30-50 lakhs for 1 bhk of around 600-800 sq.feet. Income of middle class population is around rs. 3-5 lakh yearly. In 5 lakhs 3.5 lakhs will be spent in consumption. It means rs.1.5 lakh can be maximum saving in year if medical bills are ignored. So, that it will take around 30 years for a middle class to accumulate 50 lakhs rs. But in 30 years , house will cost 1.5 crore rs. So, for middle class people, its impossible to own a house in this Indian economy. Cost of marriages, education, medical bills also ignored in above analysis.
Series of lies in this budget, middle class cannot afford a piece of land or house.

Multi dimensional poverty as quoted by the FM Mrs Sitharaman depends on the basic capabilities to find out poverty and a general term of poverty includes income poverty as measured by the UNDP at 1.25 dollars a day , this is not a fair number and thats why the government actually gives you a more clear picture about what they are doing . 

As for the housing system , they already reached 2.94 crore households under government schemes that is almost everyone in rural areas and 51% of urban poor have been reached , urban poor as we know is lesser in terms of the rural poor . 

When we talk about the targets set under the 4 pillars and make in india concerning ur argument with unemployment that has been largely due to covid and the huge amount dedicated to the EV sector and railways is bound to make it more efficient for our country to get back to the jobs we actually want to have , aside from that in priority sectors like energy india is saving money and as for defence , they have continued to reduce the import % and have shown tendency of self reliance . Coming to the 4 pillars , these were objectives set by the government for this budget , they never advertised it as main targets before except the double income of farmers where i agree , but the 4 pillars where they talk about have been well supported in this budget . 

Coming to the 5 trillion objective , government dint have some sick dream that Covid would happen along with the russia ukraine war and thats why their targets have been much more conservative keeping in mind the natural disasters , they indeed have given many fresh deadlines for what they couldnt achieve in terms of say irrigation and other projects , it is people like you who provide this half baited  you , no data available applies to you because you are a propagada merchant

The firecracker factory located on the Magardha road, Harda was illegally running since many years. The owner Raju Agrawal and brother Somesh Agrawal were having political support by which they were running this business in which more than 2500 workers used to work. Apart from this factory he is owning some more illegal factories of firecrackers which are still not sealed. According to many workers who ran and saved their lives, only 500-600 people managed to come out of it. 60 to 80 houses were situated near the factory which is equal to a village. All of their houses turned into ashes after this blast. Many people are still missing, more than 300 people have lost their lives and a lot of people got injured that some are referred to Indore, Bhopal, Narmadapuram and Khandwa. People those who have lost their houses, came on the road. Administration was making fool to people telling that "CM will visit Harda to meet you all" but when he visited he just went in the hospital, met 3-4 patients then visited the location where the incident took place but a through a seperate way. He didn't even interacted with the people who were waiting for him since 24 hours empty stomach. People lost their loved ones, urging for help but no one is their to help them. Even the media and politians are showing just "11 died" instead of telling the truth in this very hard time.

CM अरविंद केजरीवाल पर चलेगा मानहानि का मुकदमा, दिल्ली हाईकोर्ट का केस रद्द करने से इनकार

Defamation Case दिल्ली के मुख्यमंत्री अरविंद केजरीवाल (Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal) की मुश्किलें फिर से बढ़ सकती हैं। यूट्यूबर के वीडियो को री-पोस्ट करने के मामले में उनपर मानहानि का मुकदमा चलेगा। सीएम अरविंद केजरीवाल ने दिल्ली हाईकोर्ट में निचली अदालत द्वारा मानहानि मामले में समन जारी करने के आदेश को चुनौती दी थी। इसे हाईकोर्ट ने खारिज कर दिया।

By Vineet TripathiEdited By: GeetarjunPublished: Mon, 05 Feb 2024 04:13 PM (IST)Updated: Mon, 05 Feb 2024 04:13 PM (IST)

￼￼यूट्यूबर के वीडियो को री-ट्वीट करने के मामले में अरविंद केजरीवाल पर चलेगा मानहानि मुकदमा।

जागरण संवाददाता, नई दिल्ली। दिल्ली के मुख्यमंत्री अरविंद केजरीवाल (Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal) की मुश्किलें फिर से बढ़ सकती हैं। यूट्यूबर के वीडियो को री-पोस्ट करने के मामले में उनपर मानहानि का मुकदमा चलेगा। अरविंद केजरीवाल ने दिल्ली हाईकोर्ट में निचली अदालत द्वारा मानहानि मामले में समन जारी करने के आदेश को चुनौती दी थी।

￼

इसे हाईकोर्ट ने खारिज कर दिया। दिल्ली हाईकोर्ट ने भाजपा आईटी सेल (BJP IT Cell) पर यूट्यूबर ध्रुव राठी के एक वीडियो को री-ट्वीट करने पर अरविंद केजरीवाल के खिलाफ दायर आपराधिक मानहानि मामले को रद्द करने से इनकार कर दिया।

अदालत ने कहा कि अरविंद केजरीवाल को बड़ी संख्या में लोग फॉलो करते हैं और वह वीडियो को री-पोस्ट करने के परिणामों को समझते हैं। अपमानजनक सामग्री को री-पोस्ट करना मानहानि के समान है। अदालत ने यह निष्कर्ष निकाला कि केजरीवाल का कथित रूप से अपमानजनक सामग्री को शेयर (साझा) करना एक प्रकार से सार्वजनिक समर्थन के समान है और वह ऐसी सामग्री पोस्ट करने के नतीजों को समझते हैं।

- The Union Budget 2024 was presented by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman as an Interim Budget due to the upcoming Lok Sabha elections.
- Interim budgets provide estimates for the upcoming year and outline government spending plans until a new government is formed.
- The main focus of the budget was Capital Expenditure (CAPEX) for infrastructure projects like roads, railways, and ports, with an 11.1% increase in allocation to ₹11.11 trillion.
- Railway allocation increased to ₹2.55 trillion, with plans for new corridors and converting normal rail coaches to Vande Bharat standards.
- In the agriculture sector, initiatives like Atmanirbhar Oil Seeds Abhiyan and Nano-DAP were announced to promote self-reliance in seeds and eco-friendly fertilizers.
- However, subsidies for fertilizers and food were reduced compared to the previous year's budget.
- Education and healthcare sectors saw budget cuts in certain areas, despite a slight increase in overall education spending to ₹1.25 trillion.
- The government emphasized spending on central universities and research, while healthcare spending increased to ₹900 billion, focusing on expanding the Ayushman Bharat scheme and cervical cancer vaccination.
- The Prime Minister Awas scheme received increased allocation for affordable housing, with plans for a new scheme for middle-class individuals living in rented houses, slums, or unauthorized colonies.
- India's projected real GDP growth rate for 2023-2024 is 7.3%, with various international agencies projecting similar growth rates.
- The budget aims to reduce the fiscal deficit to 5.1% of GDP for 2024-2025.
- Major expenses include interest servicing, with an increase in spending to ₹11.9 trillion.
- Taxes for common people remained unchanged, with borrowing being the largest revenue source.
- The Finance Minister's tagline for the budget was "Viksit Bharat by 2047," emphasizing India's development goals.
- The budget focused on welfare for the poor, women, youth, and farmers, aiming for overall societal progress.
- Critics have highlighted data gaps in various areas, questioning the government's transparency and effectiveness in addressing key issues.
- Detailed insights and further information are expected with the presentation of the full budget in July.

- Union Budget 2024 is an Interim Budget presented by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman due to upcoming Lok Sabha elections.
- The focus remains on Capital Expenditure (CAPEX), with a 11.1% increase to ₹11.11 trillion, emphasizing infrastructure projects for economic growth and job creation.
- Railway budget increases to ₹2.55 trillion, with allocations for new corridors and safety enhancements after recent accidents.
- Agriculture sector sees initiatives like Atmanirbhar Oil Seeds Abhiyan and Nano-DAP, aiming for self-sufficiency and eco-friendly farming.
- Education and healthcare sectors witness mixed changes, with budget cuts in some areas but increases in others, reflecting varied priorities.

इससे और पहले चलते हैं तो हमारे देश में जब राजा - महाराजाओं की राज चलती थी तो बहुत लोगों के साथ अन्याय होता था, उनका भी बदला लेंगे हमारे प्रधानमंत्री ।

मुगलों ने राज किया, इनका तो बदला लेकर ही रहेंगे।
और सम्राट अशोक ने कलिंग युद्ध में लाखों लोगों जिसमें कि बच्चें बूढ़े एवं महिलाएँ भी सामिल थी उनको काटा गया, इतनी ज्यादा खून बहाया गया कि उसका हृदय परिवर्तन हो गया।
इन सबका बदला लेंगे हमारे प्रधान मंत्री, और इन सभी घटनाओं का उल्लेख तो साफ साफ है इतिहास के पनों में, इसलिए इस चीज का फैसला करने/ करवाने में सुप्रीम् कोर्ट को ज्यादा समय भी नहीं लगेगा जितना कि बाबरी मस्जिद केस में लगा।

और इससे बहुत पिछे त्रेतायुग युग में चलें तो कैकयी ने राजा दशरथ से हमारे प्रभु श्री राम जी को १४ वर्ष का वनवास कराया तो बिल्कुल भी माफ करने योग्य नहीं है, जिस तरह वो आज राम मंदिर में विराजमान है, वैसे ही वो उस समय की अयोध्या की राजा बनकर रहना चाहिए था।
अभी तो हमारे राम झुग्गी झोपड़ियां में रहते थे लेकिन अपने जीवन काल में जो 14 वर्ष का वनवास का बदला हमलोग लेकर रहेंगे।

और इससे पहले चलें तो सबसे पहले इस पृथ्वी पर डायनासोर का वास हुआ करता था, यह धरती पर सिर्फ उनका हक है। यह धरती जिसकी थी पहले उसे लौटा देना चाहिए।


हम सब मिलकर इस चीज के लिए    आवाज उठा सकते हैं। हमारे प्रधानमंत्री नरेन्द्र मोदी ही इस कार्य को कर सकते है।

🎯 Key Takeaways for quick navigation:

00:00 📅 *Overview of Interim Budget*
- Interim Budget announcement on February 1, 2024.
- Explanation of the significance of Interim Budgets during election years and their impact on government spending strategy.
01:00 🏗️ *Focus on Capital Expenditure (CAPEX)*
- Government's emphasis on Capital Expenditure for economic growth.
- Increase in CAPEX by 11.1%, totaling ₹11.11 trillion in the budget.
- Specific allocation for railways, including three new corridors and conversion of rail coaches to Vande Bharat standards.
03:08 🌾 *Agriculture and Fertilizer Initiatives*
- Introduction of Atmanirbhar Oil Seeds Abhiyan and promotion of Nano-DAP fertilizer.
- Aim to reduce edible oil imports from 60% to 30% for self-reliance.
- Reduction in fertilizer and food subsidies in the budget.
04:34 🏫 *Education and Healthcare Budget Cuts*
- Education budget increased to ₹1.25 trillion, but cuts in allocations for UGC, IITs, and IIMs.
- Reduction in healthcare spending compared to last year.
- Emphasis on increased spending for central universities, research, and innovation.
06:26 🏡 *Housing and Affordable Housing Scheme*
- Increase in allocation for the Prime Minister Awas scheme to ₹806.71 billion.
- Introduction of a new scheme for the middle class to build and buy houses.
- Emphasis on affordable housing for the poor.
07:54 💰 *Economic Growth and GDP Projections*
- Projections for India's real GDP growth rate at 7.3% for 2023-2024.
- Comparison of Nominal GDP and Real GDP.
- Mention of various international agencies' projections for India's GDP growth rate.
09:24 🎓 *Focus on Reducing Fiscal Deficit*
- Explanation of Fiscal Deficit and its target set at 5.1% of GDP for 2024-2025.
- Historical context of the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act, 2003.
- Overview of government spending on interest servicing.
11:48 📊 *Major Government Expenses and Tax Revenue*
- Breakdown of major government expenses based on the budget.
- Insight into tax revenue sources, with a focus on Income Tax, GST, and Corporate Tax.
- Mention of borrowing being the largest source of government income.
13:44 📉 *Comparison of Economic Promises*
- Critique of unfulfilled economic promises, including the $5 trillion economy by 2024.
- Skepticism about new promises, with the $7 trillion economy by 2030.
- Historical context of previous unmet deadlines and promises.
14:52 👥 *Social Sections Addressed in the Budget*
- Finance Minister's focus on the welfare of poor people, women, youth, and farmers.
- Criticism of the government's performance in areas such as hunger index, youth unemployment, and women's labor participation.
- Analysis of income changes across different sections of the population.
17:42 🤷 *Conclusion and Critique*
- Recap of the Interim Budget and anticipation for the full budget in July.
- Criticism of the lack of transparency in government data disclosure.
- Examination of contradictory statements regarding poverty reduction.

We might be late for 5 trillion mark but we won't be late to become developed economy. It's just not government responsibility to achieve these targets but a responsibility of each citizen to make this dream come true as soon as possible, by adding there efforts to these goals.

Tax Calculation as per old regime for those anpadh jo naach rahe hai

Income 9.5 Lakh
Less deductions 
1.Under sec. 80C- Rs.1.5 Lakh
2.Housing Loan Interest - 2 Lakh
3.Additional under 80D or any other -Rs. 1 Lakh

Now income after deduction is Rs. 5 lakh
Tax rebate of Rs.12500 and hence complete tax is zero.

The Union Budget in India holds significant importance as it outlines the government's financial plan for the upcoming fiscal year. It details revenue and expenditure allocations across various sectors, reflecting the government's priorities and policies. Citizens, businesses, and investors closely analyze the budget as it can impact taxes, subsidies, and overall economic direction. The budget's success is crucial for economic stability, growth, and addressing key issues in the country.
